speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument next in Case 12-1408, United States v. Quality Stores. Mr. Feigin.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, don't we have a Alderson Reporting Company decision that says that the -- the term "wages" should be interpreted the same way for FICA purposes and income tax?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Either then or now, were the supplemental unemployment benefit payments subject to FICA withholding or are they now exempt under the present --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And after (o) was passed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It's obviously subject to Federal income tax withholding.  What about FICA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Okay.  And is that still true now?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why -- I might have missed a step here.  Why were they getting big tax bills if they're not wages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I have a question about the effect of the government's position. In the States, if these -- if we say these Alderson Reporting Company benefits qualify as wages for FICA purposes, then what about the States that say we will supply unemployment compensation only if there is not another source of unemployment compensation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it ever to the long-term advantage to the employee to have FICA withholding, so that the employee's account is greater and the benefits are greater?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if the payments were not keyed to the length of service and to salary?  It was just a flat severance payment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, in the Coffy case, the Court drew a distinction between compensation for services and payments that are contingent on the employee's being thrown out of work.  But that -- why doesn't that apply here?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Hertzberg.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What are you saying, "SUB payments"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not hip.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can you win at all if I think their regulation is irrational and contrary to the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I know that's not before Alderson Reporting Company us, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- how do you win, assuming I just say I don't pay any attention to the regulation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Isn't it easier to withhold taxes on both?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Isn't it easier to withhold taxes on both?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If it is treated for Alderson Reporting Company income tax purposes as wages, why shouldn't it be treated for FICA tax purposes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What your are saying is on the income side they are treated as wages; on the FICA side they're not treated as wages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why are they giving them the money, just out of love?  I mean, they don't give it to me when I retire.  They only give it to their employees when they retire.  What -- what are they paying them for?  Aren't they paying them for faithful and good past services?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: just being generous? No, what they're doing is No, they are -- they are Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why don't they do that for me?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There are some severance payments that do count for FICA purposes, isn't that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What if Section 3402(o) did not exist?  Would these severance payments fall within FICA's definition of wages then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It is, but it -- really, if you have anything -- the definition is very broad.  I mean, it says "'wages' means all remuneration for employment."  All remuneration -- wages means all remuneration for employment paid basically for any service of whatever nature performed by an employee. Now, I agree with you that it's the same definition for the withholding.  But Congress, it passes the withholding change with conflicting interpretations. So it wouldn't be the first time that Congress passed a statute to say:  We don't care what the conflicting interpretations are; ignoring that, you are going to withhold this money, period.  And it said, whether it's other than wages or not. I grant you, they might have thought they had to pass it, but so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: We could also look at it as they didn't have to pass it.  It was subject to withholding anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, no, there would have been a need, if different people think different things. So you want to be sure. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, Congress does that quite a lot.  It -- it --  on certain, different people tell them different things.  They say, we don't care; do it anyway.  And that's what this statute basically says: Withhold anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And maybe -- could we say that?  Could we say, well, in our opinion you are right. Both statutes cover supplemental unemployment benefits. It's never come up in the other context since this because Congress wanted to be sure it was withheld.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Could you review again, what is -- what is the relevant distinction between dismissal payments that are subject to FICA and payments that are not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It has to be involuntary?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And SUB payments are all voluntary?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You -- well, you told me that the dismissal payments are involuntary.  How about the supplemental?  Are they ever and always voluntary? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'll take it that you're right, that the Congress that passed the withholding statute thought it fell outside of the definition of wages, but they were wrong. Now, that wouldn't be the first time either. So -- but Congress did think it.  So what weight am I supposed to give to what Congress thought then about what an earlier Congress, namely, the Congress that passed the wage definition in the withholding statute thought?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, yes.  But that was so much the more so, you see?  They had authority saying it wasn't wages.  That doesn't mean that authority was correct.  And -- and so that's why they passed the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, the government explains 3402(o) on the ground that there had been prior admin -- IRS administrative decisions exempting certain types of SUB payments from the definition of wages.  And that -- that can explain that language.  The language that they are -- that SUB payments are to be treated as if they were wages doesn't necessarily mean that all of those SUB payments are not wages. It does necessarily mean that at least some of them -- or suggests at least some of them are not wages.  So what's wrong with the government's explanation of the language along those lines.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was the earlier statute definition of wages for tax purposes, was that reenacted at the same time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you really have -- you call into play the principle that you should interpret a statute to make sense and not interpret any provision to be superfluous, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you say that the government's interpretation renders (o) superfluous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We'll ask him about that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Feigin, 18 minutes. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You were touching at what I was thinking.  Why don't you answer Justice Scalia's point.  Why is (o) not superfluous?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You have to acknowledge, though, that if you read -- if you read the two sections of the statute together, the one seems to be unnecessary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "Wages" means all remuneration, including cash value of all remuneration, including benefits.  And then (o) says "extension of withholding of certain payments other than wages.  For purposes of this chapter, any supplemental and unemployment compensation benefit paid to an individual shall be treated as if it were a payment of wages," suggesting that it really isn't. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, there would have been a way to fix the revenue rulings without doing it this way.  Couldn't they have done it some other way without enacting a statute that contradicted itself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, unless it was in a section that said how to treat men who are not 6 feet tall.  The title of this section (o), "extension of withholding to certain payments other than wages."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, it -- it clearly suggests that these are not wages. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How about that we should just ignore their revenue rulings, including the current one, and just deal with the statute?  Is that what you are suggesting?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I think part of the -- the point is that the broad, capacious Alderson Reporting Company definition of "wages" at least doesn't seem as broad to the IRS since they are carving things out, maybe not willy-nilly, but at least they don't seem that it's as broad as you do -- they don't seem to think that it's as broad as you do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And then what happens to the State compensation schemes which the revenue rulings seem to have been trying to accommodate?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
